v = iR (Ohm's Law)

Also: i = Gv where G = 1/R

Power: P = vi = i²R = v²/R

Time domain: i = C dv/dt

Integral form: v = (1/C)∫i dt

Charge: q = Cv

Time domain: v = L di/dt

Integral form: i = (1/L)∫v dt

Flux: φ = Li

Z_L = jωL

Magnitude: |Z_L| = ωL

Phase: +90° (voltage leads current)

W_C = ½Cv² = ½q²/C

Energy stored in electric field

No energy dissipation (ideal)

W_L = ½Li² = ½φ²/L

Energy stored in magnetic field

No energy dissipation (ideal)

i = I_s(e^(v/nV_T) - 1)

I_s = saturation current (~10⁻¹² A)
V_T = thermal voltage (≈26mV at 25°C)
n = ideality factor (1-2)

r_d = V_T/I_D = nV_T/I_D

At I_D = 1mA: r_d = 26Ω

Derived from slope of V-I curve

From i = C dv/dt:

Instant change → dv/dt = ∞
This requires i = ∞ (impossible)

Capacitor voltage MUST be continuous

From v = L di/dt:

Instant change → di/dt = ∞
This requires v = ∞ (impossible)

Inductor current MUST be continuous

Saturation region:
I_D = (k/2)(V_GS - V_TH)²

k = μ_n C_ox (W/L)

Transconductance: g_m = √(2k·I_D)

Resonant frequency: ω₀ = 1/√(LC)

At resonance:
• Z = R (purely resistive)
• |Z| is minimum
• Current is maximum
